title: Price Tags
statementHtml:
Imagine that you are the owner of a store. Before the start of a new season, you decided to clear your store of leftover goods, and therefore you decided to hold a total sale.

You have nn different items in your store: the ii-th item costs cici coins. Each item has a price tag with the corresponding price cici. You decided to hold a sale in the format: "we divided all the prices xx times." Formally, this means that you choose a common coefficient xx, and during the sale, the ii-th item will cost ⌈cix⌉⌈cix⌉ coins (where ⌈y⌉⌈y⌉ denotes rounding up).

To avoid confusion among the customers, you need to pin new price tags with new prices on all items, but printing new price tags is costly. Specifically, each printed price tag will cost you yy coins.

Therefore, you had a brilliant idea — why not use the existing price tags and simply repin them on other items? So, you'll need to print price tags only for those items that do not have a corresponding price tag available.

There remains one last question: by how much should you reduce the prices, or what xx should you choose? The coefficient xx must be an integer strictly greater than 11 and such that the total income is maximized. The total income is equal to the total value of the items minus the cost of the printed price tags.

Determine the maximum possible total income.
inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤101≤t≤10) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and yy (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105; 1≤y≤1091≤y≤109) — the number of items and the cost of printing one price tag.

The second line contains nn integers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn (1≤ci≤2⋅1051≤ci≤2⋅105) — the initial prices of the items.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the maximum total income.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, it is optimal to choose x=3x=3. The new prices of the items will be [17,50,17,50,50][17,50,17,50,50]. In this case, we can use two old price tags of 5050, and we will have to print three price tags for 1717, 1717, and 5050. As a result, the income will be 17+50+17+50+50−51⋅3=3117+50+17+50+50−51⋅3=31.

In the second test case, it is optimal to choose x=2x=2. The new prices will be [21,21,21][21,21,21], and we will have to print 33 new price tags.

In the third test case, it is optimal to choose x=111x=111.

In the fourth test case, it is optimal to choose x=2x=2. The new prices will be the same as the old ones, so no new price tags will be printed.
tutorialHtml:
Let A=maxai. Firstly, if x>A then the answer for x will be the same as for x−1, since for each i value ⌈aix⌉=⌈aix−1⌉=1. In other words, there is no need to check x-s bigger than A (the corner case is when A=1).

Suppose we fixed some value x. Each ⌈aix⌉≤⌈Ax⌉, so all resulting prices are bounded by ⌈Ax⌉. So, if we somehow calculate the answer for x in O(Ax) time, we can achieve a pretty fast solution in total, since A∑x=1O(Ax)=O(AlogA).

So, how to calculate the answer for a fixed x? For the start, let's precalculate some statistics: let's calculate the array cnt where cnt[p] is the number of initial price tags equal to p. This array can be calculated once, since it doesn't change for different x.

Next, let's iterate over all p from 1 to ⌈Ax⌉. What initial prices will result in p? It's prices in the segment [(p−1)⋅x+1,p⋅x] and we can calculate their number (let's name it as need) asking a sum on a segment in the array cnt that can be done in O(1) using prefix sums.

Since there are exactly cnt[p] existing price tags, we'll need max(0,need−cnt[p]) extra tags to print. In total, the resulting price p will contribute to the total income exactly p⋅need−y⋅max(0,need−cnt[p]) coins.

As a result, we can calculate an income for each x in O(Ax) time that gives us the total complexity O(n+AlogA) per test.
